poem:
"In Honor of Morality's Cloak"

Mourn not the script,
Etched in timeless stone—
but the hand, soft 
against hardened law. 

Lowered into the Panthéon,
a lawyer whispers without words,
His name's echo banishing potent death,
Alive, still, in the moral conscience.

See Robert Badinter,
See the quiet revolution
-of love over law-
Ninety-five winters strong,
Finally yielding to inevitable spring.
